title: Where would the United States of America empire rank in history compared to the other great empires in history? - Quora

response.answer_text: The term “empire” is a little nebulous, but the USA is an empire in the same sense that classical Athens was an empire. In both cases, various dependencies and territories extend the rule of the government outside the nation from which the government is derived. If we are going to rank empires, however, we will need a better definition of what counts as an empire and how to rank them. Maybe it’s better for now just to name winners in different categories. Largest by percent of land area — the British Empire, with 24%, in 1920. Largest by percent of population — the Persian Empire, with 44%, ~480 BC. Longest lasting — Guinness awards the title to the Roman Empire, but Japan has had the same ruling dynasty for 1500 - 2680 years. The United States would compete in the categories “Strongest by percent of military expenditure” (36% in 2017) and “Richest by percent of economic output” (50% in 1950). I am not sure it would win either category, though.

The United States of America is not now, nor has it ever been, an empire. For one thing… we have never had a ruling Emperor. Our Chief Executive, The President, is elected by a Constitutionally mandated electoral process and is limited to two four year terms in office by the U.S. Constitution(as amended) not the lifetime tenure often given to Emperors, and is subject to impeachment and removal from office if tried and convicted by members of the Congress, acting in this case as a court with appropriate trial procedures. Hardly an Imperial rule!! The world should be very thankful that the U.S. is NOT an empire, for if it was, and sought to expand its power as Empires often do, and fought as ruthlessly to extend its dominion as did the Assyrian, Persian, Roman, Mongol, and in modern times, the Nazi, Soviet, or Japanese Empires, all nations now complaining of an American Empire would experience one… those few who survived!!
